citation.biblCit: Huang, Vivian; Elahi, Shokrollah; Madsen, Karen; Fedorak, Richard; Dieleman, Levinus; Wine, Eytan; Dunsmore, Garett, 2016, "Immunological Profiling", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10903, UAL Dataverse, V2

prodStmt.producer: Preconception and Pregnancy in Inflammatory Bowel Disease Clinical Research Program

stdyInfo.abstract: This study aims to answer the question: why do some women flare during pregnancy, while others go into remission? It looks at changes in cytokines and the immune profile during pregnancy in women with IBD, comparing longitudinal changes by IBD disease types and disease activity, and comparing this to healthy volunteers. As well, outcomes, like preterm delivery, are tracked.

sumDscr.universe: Adult women with IBD enrolled in the Preconception and Pregnancy in IBD clinic and healthy volunteers.

dataColl.frequenc: Blood samples were collected at preconception, in each trimester of pregnancy, and cord blood will be collected at birth. Blood samples are also collected if enrolled patients visit the clinic at any point due to flaring or other related issues.
dataColl.sampProc: 30 study participants were chosen as the sample size so as to have 10 women with Crone's disease, 10 with ulcerative colitis, and 10 healthy controls.
dataColl.collMode: Self-administered questionnaire: Paper; Physical measurements and tests;

setAvail.avlStatus: Data is not available because the study is still recruiting.

useStmt.conditions: Access to deidentified data may be permitted for external researchers, with limitations. Only researchers with REB-approved projects may be permitted access to the deidentified data. A basic data sharing agreement form is required (ie. Agree to not attempt to re-identify the records so as to relate the information on the file to a particular person). The data producer determines access on a case-by-case basis. Contact the data producer directly to discuss terms and conditions of access.

othrStdyMat.relStdy: Effects of Maternal IBD and IBD Breast Milk on Neonatal Gut Microbiome and Intestinal Inflammation
Elevated Fecal Calprotectin in the Second or Third Trimester of Pregnancy Predicts Preterm Delivery in Women with IBD

otherMat.txt: "Inflammatory Cytokines Change during Pregnancy in Women with IBD" poster presentation. The presentation contains aggregate data tables.
